G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Under G.L. c. 208, § 28, a modification of custody orders is warranted when a material and substantial change in circumstances has occurred that affects the welfare of the children, and where modification would serve their best interests.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 209C, § 20 and G.L. c. 208, § 28, as the modifications sought pertain to the custody and visitation of minor children residing in the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.

MGL c. 265.proposition: Since that time, the Defendant has entered a live-in relationship with **[Partner's Name]**, who has: a. **A criminal record, including a conviction for assault and battery**, in violation of MGL c. 265; b. A history of domestic violence, evidenced by a restraining order issued against him by a previous romantic partner, as documented in [Court or Case Details, if known].

Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: The presence of Defendant's cohabitating partner with a history of violence and concerning behavior constitutes a **"material and substantial change in circumstances"** that was unforeseen at the time of the original custody order. See Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012) (noting that courts may modify custody orders when unforeseen changes affect the child's welfare).
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: The opinion in Hunter v. Rose is a custody and parentage case focused on recognition of a California domestic partnership and application of the best-interests standard. It does not discuss modification of a prior custody order, the legal standard for a “material and substantial change in circumstances,” or unforeseen changes such as the presence of a cohabiting partner with a history of violence. The cited case therefore does not provide authority for that specific modification standard or scenario.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: “Parents have an equal right to custody of their children. … ‘In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry [is] … what is “best for the child” ….’ … The judge shall consider ‘whether or not the child’s present or past living conditions adversely affect his physical, mental, moral or emotional health.’ G. L. c. 208, § 31. Factors a judge may weigh are whether one parent’s home is more stable… and whether one parent seeks to undermine the relationship a child has with the other parent.”

Care and Protection of Georgette, 439 Ma.raw_text: Care and Protection of Georgette, 439 Mass. 28, 34 (2003)
Care and Protection of Georgette, 439 Ma.proposition: The safety and welfare of the children are paramount considerations in any custody or visitation matter. See Care and Protection of Georgette, 439 Mass. 28, 34 (2003).
Care and Protection of Georgette, 439 Ma.support_reasoning: The excerpt focuses on ineffective assistance of counsel, conflicts in representing multiple children, and standards for child representation. While it repeatedly notes the State’s and courts’ interest in protecting the welfare of children, it does not clearly state or frame a rule that in any custody or visitation matter the children’s safety and welfare are the paramount considerations. The proposition slightly overstates what is expressly articulated in the provided text, which treats welfare as very important but not in the precise, categorical way quoted.
Care and Protection of Georgette, 439 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “[The motion was]…subversive of the finality that children’s cases require; and…productive of undue hardship and delay of the sort to be avoided in proceedings involving the State’s important interest in protecting the welfare of children.” … “Given the overwhelming evidence of the father’s unfitness… it was not in Georgette’s and Lucy’s best interests to be returned to his care…. ”

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31A.proposition: Massachusetts law strongly favors protecting children from exposure to domestic violence and other harmful environments, as emphasized in G.L. c. 208, § 31A and Mass. G.L. c. 209A, which recognize the significant impact of domestic violence on a child’s well-being.

Mass. G.L. c. 209A.proposition: Massachusetts law strongly favors protecting children from exposure to domestic violence and other harmful environments, as emphasized in G.L. c. 208, § 31A and Mass. G.L. c. 209A, which recognize the significant impact of domestic violence on a child’s well-being.

Loebel v. Loebel, 77 Mass. App. Ct. 740.raw_text: Loebel v. Loebel, 77 Mass. App. Ct. 740 (2010)
Loebel v. Loebel, 77 Mass. App. Ct. 740.proposition: Courts have the discretion to impose supervised visitation or other restrictions when necessary to protect children. See Loebel v. Loebel, 77 Mass. App. Ct. 740 (2010).
Loebel v. Loebel, 77 Mass. App. Ct. 740.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses standards for determining child custody and the need to consider the children’s best interests and domestic violence, but it does not address supervised visitation or specific restrictions on visitation as a protective measure. The court neither imposes supervised visitation nor analyzes judicial discretion to order supervised or otherwise restricted visitation. Therefore, this case does not provide authority for the specific proposition that courts may impose supervised visitation or similar restrictions to protect children.
Loebel v. Loebel, 77 Mass. App. Ct. 740.relevant_excerpt: “When determining child custody awards in general, or modifications of custody awards based on changed circumstances, the guiding principle always has been the best interests of the children. . . . ‘The decision of which parent will promote a child’s best interests is a subject peculiarly within the discretion of the judge.’ Discretion allows the judge when determining the best interests of children, to consider the widest range of permissible evidence….”
